title: Will the WHO confirm more than 10 cases of Marburg in 2017?
preds: No. The incubation period is 21 days. They may find that there are more cases, but certainly nothing will be announced so quickly.

since there have been cases already..it is more likely that more cases will arise...and if it is similar to ebola.....that spread rapidly but was curtailed due to quick and courageous work.nonetheless these are days in which diseases will increase as population and wars continue to grow.
Only 3 cases as of the middle of November and they have gotten control of it.
Based on the updates provided by WHO, it appears the outbreak is contained.
There may exist 10 cases. Confirming them in such a small span of time is unlikely.
3 confirmed deaths and WHO says disease under control so unlikely that they would report another 7.

While the efforts of Ugandan and Kenyan health agencies, along with the WHO, have done well to minimize the chance of outbreak, there is still some risk.  The risk is due in large part to the fact that the origin is neither certain nor contained.  The suspected fruit bat population still exists in proximity to people.  I doubt that 7 new cases will emerge in the next few days, but it is certainly possible if unlikely.
It hasn't spread fast enough to be on track for ten cases at this point
So far there are only 3 cases, and the year is almost over, with no more cases in a couple of months.
Marburg is lethal, but seems to be less prevalent than its cousin Ebola.

Given that the WHO declared the Ugandan Marburg crisis "controlled" as of 08 December (http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/releases/2017/uganda-marburg-virus-disease/en/), the organization is extremely unlikely to reverse itself by publicizing (in the remaining days of 2017) an increase in the number of cases.

Africa and the rest of the world learned a lot from the Ebola pandemic. I think diagnostic tests will not be used as extensively considering the expense of rapid testing. Marburg has a lower mortality rate than Ebola. I think similar containment procedures to those employed during the ebola crisis and any outbreak will be stopped quickly-- so quickly Marburg won't be confirmed as the agent.

Current deaths are lower 2-3, multi-country UGANDA
Uganda latest - no news
Less than
It depends on how much Marburg has been confirmed in 2017, where, and how local governments are handling this, etc.

Multiple agencies have reported the initial outbreak and contact tracing have found no new infected patients . Only a week left and the possibility of multiple outbreaks is slim. Possible that a case pops out, someone went to a remote village and more than 7 get sick, but unlikely given the historical case load over the last 20 years. This bug hemoragically kills the infected quickly, and gruesomely. Unlikely it has stayed off the radar this long, but possible as it has fruit bats as a reservoir.

Three cases (2 confirmed and 1 probable) have been reported as of November 2017.  Contracts (several hundred) are under surveillance and about 2/3 - 3/4 have passed the incubation period.  Unlikely that the case number will reach 10.

As of Dec. 24, only 3 cases. All of those occurring early November. No new cases in Uganda (location of the 3 cases) nor Kenya (where one of the cases traveled while affected). Unlikely new cases will occur in the next week.
Marburg sharing a similar folk profile to Ebola makes it an easy disease to be overly cautious about.
No new information on new infections, so unless someone ate a fruit bat recently, no chance of 10 infected cases.
it appears to be contained from the orginal 3 cases.
Only three confirmed cases so far and monitoring of those in contact with those cases has nearly ended.
Uganda doesn't seem to contain it

Feels like cheating to predict at this late date.  But, I did anyway.   WHO data shows that over the past 10 years, there was only one year (2012) with 10 or more cases.   This particular outbreak appears to be isolated to one family.   On October 25th, 2017, WHO listed 155 contacts with the first and second of the three reported cases.  We're well past the point where the those exposures would've manifested into Marburg.   I could've estimated 0% but there is always a chance that someone wonders into a similar cave nearby and contracts the disease before year end.   Highly unlikely but worth a 1% chance as of today.

The potential outbreak in Uganda in October was confined to family members of a person in contact with bats that harbor the disease.  The incubation period for Marburg is 2 to 21 days so we are well beyond the point of transmission.

An outbreak would need to occur in the next 16 days. 
Wikipedia case history by year shows 7 outbreaks since 1998, indicating a it is a very low probability event. 
The 5 cases in October had contacts followed up by the WHO until 7th Decemeber without further reports of illness indicating it was contained.

Limited outbreak in October, thought to have started from exposure to a bat vector. All three who were thought to have been infected have unfortunately passed away. Their high risk contacts have completed 21/7 follow up. Generally low incidence. Three years since ~2000 where >10 cases confirmed. Less than one month for eight further cases.

WHO reports that "active surveillance of "contacts" ended 7 December  http://www.who.int/csr/don/15-november-2017-marburg-uganda-kenya/en/ng  According to above WHO communique ...As of 14 November, three cases have been reported including two confirmed cases, and one probable case. All three cases have died, resulting in a case fatality rate of 100%. The cases were epidemiologically linked and all belong to the same family.
Marburg is very difficult to diagnose, so the likelihood that WHO will confirm diagnosis in such a short time is lessened.

There has been sufficient monitoring of all contacts of the three victims. So far all have tested negative after the 21-day incubation period. Because it was such a localized outbreak in a rural area among just a few people the source of the virus has been identified which would further discourage any new infections. 
Also, there are seasonal infections or spill overs of Marburg infections  which coincide with the breeding and birthing seasons of fruit bats and in particular with young juvenile bats of approximately 6 months of age. The first infection of the hunter who lived near the caves was most likely at the end of the birthing ( August, Sept.) season when the previous babies obtain the age of 6 months. In this population of juveniles the virus has been found to be high.
http://journals.plos.org/plospathogens/article?id=10.1371/journal.ppat.1002877

It seems like an isolated outbreak of 3 cases in Uganda with no secondary infections. http://www.who.int/csr/don/15-november-2017-marburg-uganda-kenya/en/ However, the incubation period can be up to 21 days (we're past that now with these cases but there are perhaps others who would be exposed to the outbreak's natural source). http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs_marburg/en/ News has gone quiet so this is looking less likely. Consensus here is 3%. I'm going a little lower.

Three cases were all related to a single infected herder (possibly infected by a bat).  Contacts for the 3 cases have, so far, not indicated any further infections.  To put this in perspective, there are may be large numbers of bats, which are not new to the area, but have only directly infected one individual.

There were 2 cases in Uganda and one case from that in Kenya. The WHO tracked all those in contact, 500+, for the 21 days and no new cases. However, there is cave in the Region that is a tourist attraction and it is full of bats. This disease comes from bats.

Cases reported Tom WHO include cases from Uganda and Kenya.   The fatality rate has been 100% so far.  Despite small number of fatalities, Ugandan and Kenyan officials are working with the WHO to stem a from  infection to dying, all cases were I then same family.
